Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: A critical service is slowing under load and traces point to their recently merged functions
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my sister: “Movie night at my place? Haven’t seen you in ages!” I stared at the screen, guilt prickling at my conscience. We’d promised to make more time for each other, to not let work or life get in the way. She always included me in her plans, and I knew she expected the same from me. But my laptop chimed with another alert—our production service was lagging, and the traces pointed straight to the functions I’d merged yesterday. My team was counting on me to fix it, to uphold the standards of clean, efficient code. I could almost hear my manager’s voice in my head, reminding me of the importance of reliability. My sister’s message blinked on my phone, a reminder of the bond I was supposed to nurture. My code editor glared at me, demanding my attention. I felt torn, the weight of both expectations pressing down, unsure which world I was about to disappoint.
